--- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, Matt Ittigson
<cydatamatt@g...> wrote:
> On 8/17/05, stack <stack@a...> wrote:
> > Matt Ittigson wrote:
> > 
> > > I have 7 million seeds I'd like to spider.  What's the best
approach?
> > 
> > Handling big lists of seeds -- in the millions -- needs work on
our part
> > (We have an RFE: '[944987] Support case where millions of seeds' to
> > address this issue).  Its caused us trouble in the past usually in the
> > form of OOME soon after startup.
> 
> Can you point me in the right direction on this one (in case I want to
> look into taking a stab at it)?  What's the problem with so many
> seeds?  Why does the memory use continue to rise with more seeds?
> 
> [...]
I haven't looked into it too closely.  I'd guess one issue is that
they're usually all kept in memory as some form of Set.  The Set
shouldn't be that big but here is where I'd look first.

> 
> > > Just hoping to get some feedback from the Heritrix pros about
whether
> > > I'm taking the right approach to solving my problem.  My first
goal is
> > > to spider all 7 million seeds.  The second goal would be to do some
> > > spidering of on-domain pages linked to by those seeds (to discover
> > > possible new seeds).
> > >
> > Your approach sounds fine to me (Gordon and Igor might have further
> > suggestions). You might keep the list up to date with your crawls'
progress.
> 
> I can get to around 650k seeds before even the machine with 4G of RAM
> runs out.  Also, the speed isn't great as more seeds are added (that
> could be any number of factors).
>
In general, the numbers of queues and downloads are way too low for
you to be running out of memory.  Are you using a 64-bit JVM to get
the 4G of RAM?  We've not had much success with 64-bit JVMs (Crash or
premature run out of memory -- though SUSE with 142 is looks promising
according).  If a 64-bit, can you try with a 32-bit OS/JVM?

St.Ack
